>get out of visual range, kiss

>see if they like to party
>if yes, say yo, we should party together sometime, lemme get your number for this weekend
>get #
>dont hit her up until the day of, to make it seem like you have a busy life without her. Idk why it's important but it is

>repeat Path 2 every day

posts.com:
> relationships advances
> no attachment theory
I fill this gap
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attachment_theory
Tldr; Attachment theory is like when a baby and its parents have a special way of loving each other and feeling safe and close. Just like a baby needs its mommy or daddy to hold it and make sure it's okay, we all need people we can rely on and be close to as we grow up. It's how we form bonds and relationships with people, and how we learn to trust and feel safe with others. This special way of loving and feeling close is called attachment.

There are different types of attachment, some people feel secure and confident when they're with the people they care about, and others feel insecure and nervous. But no matter what, we all need people to be close to, and that's what attachment theory is all about. Understanding how we form attachments with others and how they shape our emotional and mental well-being.

>healing
https://dacemars.com/best-attachment-books/

>>28126388


There is no prison for sharing patient information. Allowed and compelled are different things.

A psych is compelled to alert authorities if a patient poses an IMMEDIATE risk of harm to themselves or others. HOWEVER, disclosure of any other patient information is handled by the code of ethics for the psych board in your country and whatever act deals with general medical privacy.

A psych can not just go broadcasting patient information all over the place whenever they want. However there's a plethora of reasons they can disclose to relevant stakeholders and it's at their sole discretion if they want to notify authorities of anything they aren't compelled to.

Recourse for violating code of ethics is through the board itself, and for violating medical privacy is through civil suit.

>>28112537
HPV is incurable, and can sometimes lead to cancer; if you get a strain which causes warts, the individual warts can be treated, but this is painful, and they will keep popping up for several years at least.

HIV is incurable; it is usually treatable, but the drugs are very expensive and can have nasty side effects; you need to take them for life. Occasionally the drugs stop working and people die.

Herpes is incurable, and infects you for life - outbreaks become less frequent with time, but they never stop; herpes simplex 2 is excruciatingly painful; there are drugs that will help treat an outbreak, but you can't take them constantly.

Chlamydia, syphilis and gonorrhoea are usually treatable with antibiotics, but antibiotic-resistant strains of gonorrhoea and syphilis are becoming steadily more common. Note that syphilis can cause insanity or death if it isn't treated, which happens more often than you'd think, because the initial symptoms disappear after a month or two, then it comes back with a vengeance years later, having quietly damaged your central nervous system in the mean time.

Hepatitis is untreatable - you will probably eventually recover from it after several years, but you'll be very sick indeed while you're waiting; it does sometimes kill.

There are other types of bacterial infection that you can pick up from sex; these are generally treatable with antibiotics.

posts.com:
Anyone dealt with OCD, particularly obsessive thoughts about death? I can't stop thinking about death. I recently started prozac which actually is helping with severe panic attacks I suffer from. I've gone from being an introvert, to realizing I was practically an extravert all along with social anxiety as now I'm super talkative and don't feel any tension around people at social gatherings (even before I drink alcohol!) Only lowered my libido a little bit compared to other SSRIs I tried.

But it hasn't stopped the OCD thoughts. It's almost like the prozac eliminated my silly little anxieties and left me focusing on the only thing my brain cannot logically decipher: Death. I think about the death of others, the aging of others, including my wife and how she will one day grow old and frail and possibly gain dementia and become a shell of her former self, a walking ghost, a distorted, messed up echo of the love of my life. All before her body finally becomes still, and I have to see her laying cold and DEAD, unmoving on a hospital bed and then a coffin. I go into this level of imagination with all of my loved ones and friends and how they will decay and eventually lay lifeless before me.

Then there's my own death. In particular, I obsess about what it would be like to die in a horrific accident. Being shot actually doesn't sound too bad. Not afraid of that for some reason, but I have a great fear of a crushing death from a car accident, plane crash, or my house collapsing from a natural disaster or nuclear event. I try to imagine in vivid detail what I will see as a plane crashes: the sudden shaking/collapsing of everything around me, what part of my body will feel the most pain/crushing sensation and how insanely painful it will be compared to any other pain I have felt in my life, the shock and adrenaline as my brain realizes what is happening and panics.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
So far, the only solace I've found is...well, thousands of humans have died in accidents similar to this before me. And they did it just fine, with no resistance, there's no stopping death when its come and taken you completely. Also what is comforting is the fact that perhaps what I imagine it would be like to be in a car crash or plane crash, maybe my imagination is making it worst than it would actually be? Maybe I'd sort of be "chill" and like "oh shit, here comes a plane crash. Ow, that hurts a shit done. Bro, am I gonna die?" Not everyone panics in every situation, even in the face of death. Maybe it won't be as traumatic as I think. And it will be over quick. PTSD is most often caused by seeing OTHERS stabbed, shot, crushed, and dismembered in front of you. It happens a lot less likely from people getting a sole injury on themselves.

But this is where I am at. The thoughts do not stop. I am a Christian but the pain of life is making my question my beliefs a bit. I pray to Jesus for help and still feel lost. I am also looking into meditation and Tibetan Buddhism, which teaches you to intentionally focus on yours and everyone's inevitable death so that compassion grows. When you see everyone around you not as a living person, but as a deluded person thinking they are going to live forever and suppressing their eventual pain and suffering and death, you gain compassion for them. I feel that. I feel my compassion has grown by focusing on this and seeing my fellow humans as sad, decaying creatures who try at all times to suppress and not think about the fact they are decaying. I have become so much more loving, and interested in doing what I can to make others happy at social gatherings.

That leaves me with my own problem, the obsessive thoughts about death. What can I do to stop them? They take up too much time and give me anxiety.

Short answer: trying to think your way out of intrusive thoughts is what creates intrusive thoughts in the first place. You are not going to logic your way out of thinking about this stuff because the part of your brain that generates anxiety, compulsions, etc (the amygdala) is not really responsive to rationalizing. It is designed to respond to threats with panic and fear in order to keep you alive, and it is misrecognizing your thoughts as a legit threat. CBT and/or mindfulness training are two really effective times ways to get anxiety and intrusive thoughts under control, also when retards on 4chan tell you to stop taking meds, IGNORE THEIR SHITTY AND DANGEROUS ADVICE

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28120647
So I think you're not actually afraid of death. You are actually afraid of the future, particularly the possibility of a painful death. The part where you are dead is not scary. In fact it is a certainty just as much as birth is a part of life. What is scary is the uncertainty leading up to death. You seem to be able to think about one thing and focus on that thing for a long time. The problem is, you are focusing on the wrong thing. You are focusing on the future, which is uncertain and also unchangeable because we can only interact with the present. This causes you to experience anxiety because you are imagining a danger, but you are not able to act to get away from the danger. In this sense, the danger is everywhere and all the time.

In OCD, there is the Obsession, which is the thought, and then the Compulsion which is the behavior in reaction to the thought which is used to remove or replace the thought with something else. E.g. "My hands are dirty. My hands are dirty. I am washing my hands. My hands are not dirty anymore, because I just washed them." In your situation, there is the thought, but no action is able to be taken to replace that thought with another.

What you should do is focus on the present. It is possible to act upon and change the present. It is not an unknown unquantifiable danger, it is known and quantifiable. Then you remove the danger and you can then relax. Focus on what is happening NOW, not what might happen later.

>>28120647
if you honestly want to think less about death, you have to address your concerns with action:

** admit to yourself that, one day, you will die either through aging or accident.
** "how do i slow down both of these occurrences from happening?"
** stop using tobacco, alcohol and drugs (yes, that also includes vaping and "medicinal marijuana").
** stop all snacking; only eat three meals a day.
** cut down your consumption of sugar to the bare minimum.
** keep a regular sleep / routine schedule. i wake up & go to sleep at around the same time everyday, regardless of weekday or weekend. admittedly, there's a tiny bit of cheating on the weekend but it's only about a half-hour difference.
** cardio for at least 45 minutes a day, every day. if not cardio, strenuous outdoor/indoor work for about an hour.
** drive the speed limit / below the speed limit if you're the only one on the road. if there's a fucktard behind you AND conditions are good, increase it a little bit just to be nice but never go above 10% above the speed limit.
** what side is the steering wheel on in your vehicle? if it's on the left, avoid left-hand turns whenever possible unless it's out of your own driveway. if the steering wheel is on the right, then avoid right-handed turns.

there you go. do that everyday and, after a few months, you will feel a bit better about yourself. there's far more beyond that, of course, but those are the the most direct health-related ones.

good luck to you.

If you can be fulfilled with online friends, I'd start with that. As you may know it can be hard for a guy to be friends with a girl if he's romantically or sexually interested in her. If things are online (and especially if you don't share pics) this becomes much harder to become an inhibition for a guy and I've been good friends (at least for a while, we kinda stopped talking at some point) with multiple chicks I met online.

I'd say it's as simple as finding spaces to discuss your interests and if you do so as a group, you'll likely find people that mesh well more with you than others and can contact them more directly. For example if you're into reading and you've gotten a good(or at least decent) impression of a guy and he posts about a book you've read you could just DM him about it and chat that way rather than in the pack. He'll likely appreciate you reaching out and you can simply keep in touch directly at that point and discuss books you've read or that you're thinking of picking up etc.

If you don't find online friendships fulfilling, I don't know how to help you because I struggle getting real life friends past college as well. I don't know where to go to find people that are also looking for the same thing and would feel somewhat weird approaching people randomly (even if say there was some superficial commonality, like at a book store)

>>28126291
Skype originally was pretty much like a phone replacement for pc. You could call phone numbers through it (paid) but you could also voice call other skype accounts. It was notorious for leaking your IP so a lot of bad stuff happened because of that. Surprised you don't know about it

Vent(rilo), Teamspeak and Mumble are a bit easier to understand you not knowing if you weren't into gaming in the earlier days but they were effectively like a discord server. You owned the server (and in most cases had to host it yourself or pay for hosting), could invite others to it and it would have text chat (although I think IIRC they weren't persistent, so you couldn't log in and see what had been posted beforehand) and different voice channels. it was basically a place to hang out and chat

>Self harmed earlier this month
I would recommend "The Dialectical Behavior Therapy Skills Workbook" by Dr. Matthew McKay. I'm sure you can find it online too if you know where to look.

>...do something good with my life to help people, not be dead.
That is a great goal, but you need to take care of yourself first.

>I split often and go into worse and worse rages.
Again, the DBT book is pretty decent until you can get a trained licensed therapist to work on distraction, mindfulness, communication, and centering.

>I am currently trying to get on antipsychotics which do not cause sedation or weight gain.
Seroquel is a rough one for weight. That said you are probably looking at something like Abilify, Risperdal, or Geodon which can have their own issues.

>My main issue is delusions, or so I am told but have begun to believe...
Being able to reality test is important. Did this worsen after stopping Seroquel? The presentation that you are stating does sound like delusional thinking patterns, but depending on the other symptoms and based on your age you are at one of the natural peaks for schizophrenia type conditions to begin to manifest. This is worrisome if these things are new onset.

You have to look at any job application from the employers perspective. What is it that YOU can bring to THEM? How does hiring YOU benefit THEM? And here's the clincher, how does the benefits YOU bring stack up against or compete with ALL THE OTHER CANDIDATES?

Btw, "they get an employee" is not an answer to that question. So you need to start at the absolute bottom in a shithole dead end job where they need employee scale but face high turnover so basically everyone who applies gets hired. That's where you need to focus your applications. Build up some work experience over 18 months and you'll be in a much better position to get employed somewhere else.

Remember, a paper qualification is meaningless in 2023 without experience.

Yes the thing is that different people fundamentally are driven by different things. Not everyone needs an empire, not everyone needs excitement, not everyone needs an adventure.
Some people are just content doing the things they like all their life: the point is that you need to find it.
THOUGH if you read OPs post, a lot of things are implicit from his post.

The thing is that it is just wrong that nothing matters. What Nihilism really means is that you belief yourself unable to affect anything that you value in any meaningful way.
Here is a mathematical proof that nihilism is wrong:
1. You do not know everything.
2. Therefore you can not know for sure that nothing has any value.
3. Also therefore it is possible that there is a way where you can increase your knowledge, since you can not know that there is none.
4. 2&3 implies that there is a positive probability that absolute meaning will be found.
5. A chance at absolute meaning is absolutely meaningful
6. therefore the pursuit is absolutely meaningful
7. absolute meaning exists

There you go. And this is just a simple proof. You can go further and make even stronger claims about the absolute meaning that exists but at least nihilism is disproven.
You can not create your own meaning, but you sure can search for it

You have created the foundation and basis for further, casual interaction, that's good. How to move it further is the next step, and entirely contextual based upon your situation, but simply sharing anecdotes tangentially related to the impetus behind your interaction is a good first step, and prompting others to then share theirs will get you going. Sharing yourself is often one of the hardest things for naturally introverted, shy, insecure people, but it's how relationships are formed with normal people; it creates a form of shared vulnerability and risk that prompts further sharing. Sharing is what friendship is at its basic level, and sharing of yourself and your life experiences is what they value.

do this tutorial first.
Then you need to make sure you understand these concepts
>topology and what makes it good or bad
>UV unwrapping and the proper techniques behind it
>Normal map baking and using Substance Painter (software)
>Texturing using Substance Painter
Now for the character specific part
>Learn to sculpt with Zbrush
>Do Anatomy studies (this will take a while)
>Learn about character design and what makes it good or bad
>Learn to rig characters so they can be animated and put in a game engine

I know that's a ton of shit but just get started with the tutorial and then try to make more complicated stuff on your own. Once you start getting comfortable just look for some online courses to guide you

Social anxiety is legitimate, which is doubly so why you feel anxious. And because it's legitimate you should stop caring. Just like death, you have every right to be scared of it, but what can you do? Nothing, except for the cessation of worry. Imagine you're born a midget and you hate yourself. What can you do? posts.com:
How do I deal with this situation?

A bit of backstory:

In 2021,

....a Former High School classmate of mine (from the mid-2000s) died.

In high school we were in some classes together, but I wasn't close with them. We did share some mutual friends, but we never hung out together.

After graduation, we all parted ways. Some of us even moved far away. Our graduating class tried to stay connected on social media. But you know how that goes. Social Media isn't a replacement for real life. We all moved on.

In 2021, the news broke on social media that my classmate died suddenly. I reached out to a mutual friend for more info. I sent my deceased classmate's family a sympathy card.

I guess they had a private funeral. I didn't hear of anything else. I was not close to their family (I never met them). All I could do was send a sympathy card and move on.

This was 2 years ago.

-------------------------

In 2023...

2 years later, suddenly out of nowhere I received a card from my deceased classmate's mother.

The mother apologized and said she's been very depressed and sad these passed 2 years. But that out of ALL sympathy cards she received, my card meant the most to her. More than any other card from other classmates, friends, or family. It really meant so much to her. (huh?)

Then the mother then asked me if she could speak with me, and even meet in-person.

--------------------

1. I have no idea why my card was the most treasured. I'm very confused. My sympathy card was nothing special. I was just polite, briefly explained who I was, and expressed my condolences for their family's loss. That's it.

How should I handle this? I'm very surprised at this message. I know there were many other people who were much closer to my former classmate than me. I feel awkward.

I'm trying to keep an open mind, but what is going on? Why is the mother contacting me 2 years later, and asking to speak to me, and meet me in person? Why me? She doesn't know me.

Thoughts?

Find it in your heart to forgive her without putting the weight on yourself. If she is trespassing your boundaries she is wrong, . there's no need to feel like you owe it to her, but you don't have to hate her either. She's old and didn't manage to learn the right lessons. it happens.

And.. probably don't expect anything from your mother. Good or bad.

TO go deeper, If you want to be free of your parents' anxiety, basically what you , or anyone, needs to do, is slowly undo parental trauma. It takes introspection, slowly going over your painful childhood memories one by one and dissolving unwarranted guilt , fear ,anger, etc. Letting go old conflicts and *gathering yourself back in when you unjustly yielded . That's how it was taught to me and how i grew out of my meekness and anxiety without having to fake myself a personality, at least.

>>28124989
If she isn't willing to engage in introspection, you'll only ever get anger or denials out of her. It's funny how some people eagerly engage in trying to improve themselves by self examining and bring brutally honest with themselves, while others completely refuse to admit they are anything but perfect. My mother is the latter as well, but she just disengages completely... the opposite of what you're experiencing. The two biggest lessons I learned from a very good therapist were 1) your guilt and discomfort are very much part of human biology, they are really primitive emotions and needing that parental approval is a leftover survival instinct. And 2) is a question she asked me - how many times do you go to the well and find out it is dry, before you accept that you're never going to get any water from it? If you can a certain that this is how she is, you can't change her, then that allows you to focus on what you can change, i.e. yourself and your situation. You sound like you have a pretty good grasp on a lot of this already, just be mindful of the guilt/anger connection, realize she is using guilt to get at you, and try to disengage from that when possible

>>28124709
Got the same issue. How do I even star a conversation to make friends?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: do difficult things that make you feel confident about talking to people, like volunteering

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Find a thing to talk about / have a reason to talk.

Join a team, a league, a club, etc. - find something you enjoy or appreciate that other people enjoy or appreciate. Then, the conversation has a clear theme/subject, and all parties are interested in it. Maybe a meet up for people who like board games, or a sport / hobby, etc. Less pressure on an individual to create conversation and more focus on the thing itself. Set yourself up for success - the topic is mutually interesting and pre-selected - and just pick up from there.
